definition[0]: to gain an advantage over an opponent, especially in politics
example[0]: The Tories found themselves outflanked by Labour on the issue of law and order.
definition[1]: to go around the side of a group of enemies during a battle and attack them from behind
definition[2]: if one company, country etc outflanks another, it is more successful than it
example[1]: For cheaper products, the Japanese outflanked Taiwan and Korea by building factories in Southeast Asia.
example[2]: It considered making a bid for the company but was outflanked by one of its competitors.
